DescrizioneColonnaCompleta: the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., a unique identifier for each person.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., a foreign key that refers to an identifier in the concept table for the unique gender of the person.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., the year of birth of the person. for data sources with date of birth, the year is extracted. for data sources where the year of birth is not available, the approximate year of birth is derived based on any age group categorization available.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., the month of birth of the person. for data sources that provide the precise date of birth, the month is extracted and stored in this field.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., the day of the month of birth of the person. for data sources that provide the precise date of birth, the day is extracted and stored in this field.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., the date and time of birth of the person.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., the date and time of death of the person.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., a foreign key that refers to an identifier in the concept table for the unique race of the person, belonging to the 'race' vocabulary.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., a foreign key that refers to the standard concept identifier in the standardized vocabularies for the ethnicity of the person, belonging to the 'ethnicity' vocabulary.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., a foreign key to the place of residency for the person in the location table, where the detailed address information is stored.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., a foreign key to the primary care provider the person is seeing in the provider table.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., a foreign key to the site of primary care in the care_site table, where the details of the care site are stored.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., an (encrypted) key derived from the person identifier in the source data. this is necessary when a use case requires a link back to the person data at the source dataset.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., the source code for the gender of the person as it appears in the source data. the personâ€™s gender is mapped to a standard gender concept in the standardized vocabularies

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., a foreign key to the gender concept that refers to the code used in the source.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., the source code for the race of the person as it appears in the source data. the person race is mapped to a standard race concept in the standardized vocabularies and the original value is stored here for reference.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., a foreign key to the race concept that refers to the code used in the source.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., the source code for the ethnicity of the person as it appears in the source data. the person ethnicity is mapped to a standard ethnicity concept in the standardized vocabularies and the original code is, stored here for reference.

the person domain contains records that uniquely identify each patient in the source data who is time at-risk to have clinical observations recorded within the source systems., a foreign key to the ethnicity concept that refers to the code used in the source.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., a unique identifier for each person's visit or encounter at a healthcare provider.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., a foreign key identifier to the person for whom the visit is recorded. the demographic details of that person are stored in the person table.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., a foreign key that refers to a visit concept identifier in the standardized vocabularies belonging to the 'visit' vocabulary.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., the start date of the visit.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., the date and time of the visit started.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., the end date of the visit. if this is a one-day visit the end date should match the start date.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., the date and time of the visit end.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., a foreign key to the predefined concept identifier in the standardized vocabularies reflecting the type of source data from which the visit record is derived belonging to the 'visit type' vocabulary.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., a foreign key to the provider in the provider table who was associated with the visit.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., a foreign key to the care site in the care site table that was visited.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., the source code for the visit as it appears in the source data.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., a foreign key to a concept that refers to the code used in the source.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., a foreign key to the predefined concept in the place of service vocabulary reflecting where the patient was admitted from.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., the source code for where the patient was admitted from as it appears in the source data.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., a foreign key to the predefined concept in the place of service vocabulary reflecting the discharge disposition for a visit.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., the source code for the discharge disposition as it appears in the source data.

the visit_occurrence table contains the spans of time a person continuously receives medical services from one or more providers at a care site in a given setting within the health care system. visits are classified into 4 settings: outpatient care, inpatient confinement, emergency room, and long-term care. persons may transition between these settings over the course of an episode of care (for example, treatment of a disease onset)., a foreign key to the visit_occurrence table of the visit immediately preceding this visit

the visit_detail table is an optional table used to represents details of each record in the parent visit_occurrence table. for every record in visit_occurrence table there may be 0 or more records in the visit_detail table with a 1:n relationship where n may be 0. the visit_detail table is structurally very similar to visit_occurrence table and belongs to the similar domain as the visit., a unique identifier for each person's visit or encounter at a healthcare provider.

the visit_detail table is an optional table used to represents details of each record in the parent visit_occurrence table. for every record in visit_occurrence table there may be 0 or more records in the visit_detail table with a 1:n relationship where n may be 0. the visit_detail table is structurally very similar to visit_occurrence table and belongs to the similar domain as the visit., a foreign key that refers to the record in the visit_occurrence table. this is a required field, because for every visit_detail is a child of visit_occurrence and cannot exist without a corresponding parent record in visit_occurrence.
the specimen domain contains the records identifying biological samples from a person., a unique identifier for each specimen.
the specimen domain contains the records identifying biological samples from a person., a foreign key identifier to the person for whom the specimen is recorded.
the specimen domain contains the records identifying biological samples from a person., a foreign key referring to a standard concept identifier in the standardized vocabularies for the specimen.

the specimen domain contains the records identifying biological samples from a person., a foreign key referring to the concept identifier in the standardized vocabularies reflecting the system of record from which the specimen was represented in the source data.
the specimen domain contains the records identifying biological samples from a person., the date the specimen was obtained from the person.
the specimen domain contains the records identifying biological samples from a person., the date and time on the date when the specimen was obtained from the person.
the specimen domain contains the records identifying biological samples from a person., the amount of specimen collection from the person during the sampling procedure.

the specimen domain contains the records identifying biological samples from a person., a foreign key to a standard concept identifier for the unit associated with the numeric quantity of the specimen collection.
the specimen domain contains the records identifying biological samples from a person., a foreign key to a standard concept identifier for the anatomic location of specimen collection.
the specimen domain contains the records identifying biological samples from a person., a foreign key to a standard concept identifier for the disease status of specimen collection.
the specimen domain contains the records identifying biological samples from a person., the specimen identifier as it appears in the source data.

the specimen domain contains the records identifying biological samples from a person., the specimen value as it appears in the source data. this value is mapped to a standard concept in the standardized vocabularies and the original code is, stored here for reference.
the specimen domain contains the records identifying biological samples from a person., the information about the unit as detailed in the source.
the specimen domain contains the records identifying biological samples from a person., the information about the anatomic site as detailed in the source.
the specimen domain contains the records identifying biological samples from a person., the information about the disease status as detailed in the source.

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., a unique identifier for each measurement.

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., a foreign key identifier to the person about whom the measurement was recorded. the demographic details of that person are stored in the person table.

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., a foreign key to the standard measurement concept identifier in the standardized vocabularies. these belong to the 'measurement' domain, but could overlap with the 'observation' domain (see #3 below).

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., the date of the measurement.

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., the date and time of the measurement. some database systems don't have a datatype of time. to accommodate all temporal analyses, datatype datetime can be used (combining measurement_date and measurement_timeÂ forum discussion)

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., the time of the measurement. this is present for backwards compatibility and will be deprecated in an upcoming version

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., a foreign key to the predefined concept in the standardized vocabularies reflecting the provenance from where the measurement record was recorded. these belong to the 'meas type' vocabulary

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., a foreign key identifier to the predefined concept in the standardized vocabularies reflecting the mathematical operator that is applied to the value_as_number. operators are <, <=, =, >=, > and these concepts belong to the 'meas value operator' domain.

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., a measurement result where the result is expressed as a numeric value.

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., a foreign key to a measurement result represented as a concept from the standardized vocabularies (e.g., positive/negative, present/absent, low/high, etc.). these belong to the 'meas value' domain

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., a foreign key to a standard concept id of measurement units in the standardized vocabularies that belong to the 'unit' domain.

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., the lower limit of the normal range of the measurement result. the lower range is assumed to be of the same unit of measure as the measurement value.

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., the upper limit of the normal range of the measurement. the upper range is assumed to be of the same unit of measure as the measurement value.

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., a foreign key to the provider in the provider table who was responsible for initiating or obtaining the measurement.

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., a foreign key to the visit in the visit_occurrence table during which the measurement was recorded.

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., a foreign key to the visit detail in the visit_detail table during which the measurement was recorded.

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., the measurement name as it appears in the source data. this code is mapped to a standard concept in the standardized vocabularies and the original code is stored here for reference.

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., a foreign key to a concept in the standard vocabularies that refers to the code used in the source.

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., the source code for the unit as it appears in the source data. this code is mapped to a standard unit concept in the standardized vocabularies and the original code is stored here for reference.

the measurement table contains records of measurement, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a person or person's sample. the measurement table contains both orders and results of such measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc., the source value associated with the content of the value_as_number or value_as_concept_id as stored in the source data.

the procedure_occurrence table contains records of activities or processes ordered by, or carried out by, a healthcare provider on the patient to have a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose. procedures are present in various data sources in different forms with varying levels of standardization., a system-generated unique identifier for each procedure occurrence.

the procedure_occurrence table contains records of activities or processes ordered by, or carried out by, a healthcare provider on the patient to have a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose. procedures are present in various data sources in different forms with varying levels of standardization., a foreign key identifier to the person who is subjected to the procedure. the demographic details of that person are stored in the person table.

the procedure_occurrence table contains records of activities or processes ordered by, or carried out by, a healthcare provider on the patient to have a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose. procedures are present in various data sources in different forms with varying levels of standardization., a foreign key that refers to a standard procedure concept identifier in the standardized vocabularies.

the procedure_occurrence table contains records of activities or processes ordered by, or carried out by, a healthcare provider on the patient to have a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose. procedures are present in various data sources in different forms with varying levels of standardization., the date on which the procedure was performed.

the procedure_occurrence table contains records of activities or processes ordered by, or carried out by, a healthcare provider on the patient to have a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose. procedures are present in various data sources in different forms with varying levels of standardization., the date and time on which the procedure was performed.

the procedure_occurrence table contains records of activities or processes ordered by, or carried out by, a healthcare provider on the patient to have a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose. procedures are present in various data sources in different forms with varying levels of standardization., a foreign key to the predefined concept identifier in the standardized vocabularies reflecting the type of source data from which the procedure record is derived, belonging to the 'procedure type' vocabulary.

the procedure_occurrence table contains records of activities or processes ordered by, or carried out by, a healthcare provider on the patient to have a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose. procedures are present in various data sources in different forms with varying levels of standardization., a foreign key to a standard concept identifier for a modifier to the procedure (e.g. bilateral). these concepts are typically distinguished by 'modifier' concept classes (e.g., 'cpt4 modifier' as part of the 'cpt4' vocabulary).

the procedure_occurrence table contains records of activities or processes ordered by, or carried out by, a healthcare provider on the patient to have a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose. procedures are present in various data sources in different forms with varying levels of standardization., the quantity of procedures ordered or administered.

the procedure_occurrence table contains records of activities or processes ordered by, or carried out by, a healthcare provider on the patient to have a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose. procedures are present in various data sources in different forms with varying levels of standardization., a foreign key to the provider in the provider table who was responsible for carrying out the procedure.

the procedure_occurrence table contains records of activities or processes ordered by, or carried out by, a healthcare provider on the patient to have a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose. procedures are present in various data sources in different forms with varying levels of standardization., a foreign key to the visit in the visit_occurrence table during which the procedure was carried out.

the procedure_occurrence table contains records of activities or processes ordered by, or carried out by, a healthcare provider on the patient to have a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose. procedures are present in various data sources in different forms with varying levels of standardization., a foreign key to the visit detail in the visit_detail table during which the procedure was carried out.

the procedure_occurrence table contains records of activities or processes ordered by, or carried out by, a healthcare provider on the patient to have a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose. procedures are present in various data sources in different forms with varying levels of standardization., the source code for the procedure as it appears in the source data. this code is mapped to a standard procedure concept in the standardized vocabularies and the original code is, stored here for reference. procedure source codes are typically icd-9-proc, cpt-4, hcpcs or opcs-4 codes.

the procedure_occurrence table contains records of activities or processes ordered by, or carried out by, a healthcare provider on the patient to have a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose. procedures are present in various data sources in different forms with varying levels of standardization., a foreign key to a procedure concept that refers to the code used in the source.

the procedure_occurrence table contains records of activities or processes ordered by, or carried out by, a healthcare provider on the patient to have a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose. procedures are present in various data sources in different forms with varying levels of standardization., the source code for the qualifier as it appears in the source data.

conditions are records of a person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a provider or reported by the patient. conditions are recorded in different sources and levels of standardization., a unique identifier for each condition occurrence event.

conditions are records of a person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a provider or reported by the patient. conditions are recorded in different sources and levels of standardization., a foreign key identifier to the person who is experiencing the condition. the demographic details of that person are stored in the person table.

conditions are records of a person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a provider or reported by the patient. conditions are recorded in different sources and levels of standardization., a foreign key that refers to a standard concept identifier in the standardized vocabularies belonging to the 'condition' domain.

conditions are records of a person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a provider or reported by the patient. conditions are recorded in different sources and levels of standardization., the date when the instance of the condition is recorded.

conditions are records of a person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a provider or reported by the patient. conditions are recorded in different sources and levels of standardization., the date and time when the instance of the condition is recorded.

conditions are records of a person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a provider or reported by the patient. conditions are recorded in different sources and levels of standardization., the date when the instance of the condition is considered to have ended.

conditions are records of a person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a provider or reported by the patient. conditions are recorded in different sources and levels of standardization., the date when the instance of the condition is considered to have ended.

conditions are records of a person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a provider or reported by the patient. conditions are recorded in different sources and levels of standardization., a foreign key to the predefined concept identifier in the standardized vocabularies reflecting the source data from which the condition was recorded, the level of standardization, and the type of occurrence. these belong to the 'condition type' vocabulary

conditions are records of a person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a provider or reported by the patient. conditions are recorded in different sources and levels of standardization., a foreign key that refers to a standard concept identifier in the standardized vocabularies reflecting the point of care at which the condition was diagnosed.

conditions are records of a person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a provider or reported by the patient. conditions are recorded in different sources and levels of standardization., the reason that the condition was no longer present, as indicated in the source data.

conditions are records of a person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a provider or reported by the patient. conditions are recorded in different sources and levels of standardization., a foreign key to the provider in the provider table who was responsible for capturing (diagnosing) the condition.

conditions are records of a person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a provider or reported by the patient. conditions are recorded in different sources and levels of standardization., a foreign key to the visit in the visit_occurrence table during which the condition was determined (diagnosed).

conditions are records of a person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a provider or reported by the patient. conditions are recorded in different sources and levels of standardization., a foreign key to the visit in the visit_detail table during which the condition was determined (diagnosed).

conditions are records of a person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a provider or reported by the patient. conditions are recorded in different sources and levels of standardization., the source code for the condition as it appears in the source data. this code is mapped to a standard condition concept in the standardized vocabularies and the original code is stored here for reference.

conditions are records of a person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a provider or reported by the patient. conditions are recorded in different sources and levels of standardization., a foreign key to a condition concept that refers to the code used in the source.

conditions are records of a person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a provider or reported by the patient. conditions are recorded in different sources and levels of standardization., the source code for the condition status as it appears in the source data. this code is mapped to a standard concept in the standardized vocabularies and the original code is stored here for reference.

the death domain contains the clinical event for how and when a person dies. a person can have up to one record if the source system contains evidence about the death., a foreign key identifier to the deceased person. the demographic details of that person are stored in the person table.

the death domain contains the clinical event for how and when a person dies. a person can have up to one record if the source system contains evidence about the death., the date the person was deceased. if the precise date including day or month is not known or not allowed, december is used as the default month, and the last day of the month the default day.

the death domain contains the clinical event for how and when a person dies. a person can have up to one record if the source system contains evidence about the death., the date and time the person was deceased. if the precise date including day or month is not known or not allowed, december is used as the default month, and the last day of the month the default day.

the death domain contains the clinical event for how and when a person dies. a person can have up to one record if the source system contains evidence about the death., a foreign key referring to the predefined concept identifier in the standardized vocabularies reflecting how the death was represented in the source data.

the death domain contains the clinical event for how and when a person dies. a person can have up to one record if the source system contains evidence about the death., a foreign key referring to a standard concept identifier in the standardized vocabularies for conditions.

the death domain contains the clinical event for how and when a person dies. a person can have up to one record if the source system contains evidence about the death., the source code for the cause of death as it appears in the source data. this code is mapped to a standard concept in the standardized vocabularies and the original code is, stored here for reference.

the death domain contains the clinical event for how and when a person dies. a person can have up to one record if the source system contains evidence about the death., a foreign key to the concept that refers to the code used in the source. note, this variable name is abbreviated to ensure it will be allowable across database platforms.
the location table represents a generic way to capture physical location or address information of persons and care sites., a unique identifier for each geographic location.

the location table represents a generic way to capture physical location or address information of persons and care sites., the address field 1, typically used for the street address, as it appears in the source data.

the location table represents a generic way to capture physical location or address information of persons and care sites., the address field 2, typically used for additional detail such as buildings, suites, floors, as it appears in the source data.
the location table represents a generic way to capture physical location or address information of persons and care sites., the city field as it appears in the source data.
the location table represents a generic way to capture physical location or address information of persons and care sites., the state field as it appears in the source data.
the location table represents a generic way to capture physical location or address information of persons and care sites., the zip or postal code.
the location table represents a generic way to capture physical location or address information of persons and care sites., the county.

the location table represents a generic way to capture physical location or address information of persons and care sites., the verbatim information that is used to uniquely identify the location as it appears in the source data.

the observation table captures clinical facts about a person obtained in the context of examination, questioning or a procedure. any data that cannot be represented by any other domains, such as social and lifestyle facts, medical history, family history, etc. are recorded here., a unique identifier for each observation.

the observation table captures clinical facts about a person obtained in the context of examination, questioning or a procedure. any data that cannot be represented by any other domains, such as social and lifestyle facts, medical history, family history, etc. are recorded here., the date of the observation.

the observation table captures clinical facts about a person obtained in the context of examination, questioning or a procedure. any data that cannot be represented by any other domains, such as social and lifestyle facts, medical history, family history, etc. are recorded here., the observation result stored as a number. this is applicable to observations where the result is expressed as a numeric value.

the observation table captures clinical facts about a person obtained in the context of examination, questioning or a procedure. any data that cannot be represented by any other domains, such as social and lifestyle facts, medical history, family history, etc. are recorded here., the observation result stored as a string. this is applicable to observations where the result is expressed as verbatim text.

the observation table captures clinical facts about a person obtained in the context of examination, questioning or a procedure. any data that cannot be represented by any other domains, such as social and lifestyle facts, medical history, family history, etc. are recorded here., a foreign key to an observation result stored as a concept id. this is applicable to observations where the result can be expressed as a standard concept from the standardized vocabularies (e.g., positive/negative, present/absent, low/high, etc.).

the observation_period table contains records which uniquely define the spans of time for which a person is at-risk to have clinical events recorded within the source systems, even if no events in fact are recorded (healthy patient with no healthcare interactions)., a unique identifier for each observation period.

the observation_period table contains records which uniquely define the spans of time for which a person is at-risk to have clinical events recorded within the source systems, even if no events in fact are recorded (healthy patient with no healthcare interactions)., a foreign key identifier to the person for whom the observation period is defined. the demographic details of that person are stored in the person table.

the observation_period table contains records which uniquely define the spans of time for which a person is at-risk to have clinical events recorded within the source systems, even if no events in fact are recorded (healthy patient with no healthcare interactions)., the start date of the observation period for which data are available from the data source.

the observation_period table contains records which uniquely define the spans of time for which a person is at-risk to have clinical events recorded within the source systems, even if no events in fact are recorded (healthy patient with no healthcare interactions)., a foreign key identifier to the predefined concept in the standardized vocabularies reflecting the source of the observation period information

the 'drug' domain captures records about the utilization of a drug when ingested or otherwise introduced into the body. a drug is a biochemical substance formulated in such a way that when administered to a person it will exert a certain physiological effect. drugs include prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vaccines, and large-molecule biologic therapies. radiological devices ingested or applied locally do not count as drugs., a system-generated unique identifier for each drug utilization event.

the 'drug' domain captures records about the utilization of a drug when ingested or otherwise introduced into the body. a drug is a biochemical substance formulated in such a way that when administered to a person it will exert a certain physiological effect. drugs include prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vaccines, and large-molecule biologic therapies. radiological devices ingested or applied locally do not count as drugs., a foreign key identifier to the person who is subjected to the drug. the demographic details of that person are stored in the person table.

the 'drug' domain captures records about the utilization of a drug when ingested or otherwise introduced into the body. a drug is a biochemical substance formulated in such a way that when administered to a person it will exert a certain physiological effect. drugs include prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vaccines, and large-molecule biologic therapies. radiological devices ingested or applied locally do not count as drugs., a foreign key that refers to a standard concept identifier in the standardized vocabularies belonging to the 'drug' domain.

the 'drug' domain captures records about the utilization of a drug when ingested or otherwise introduced into the body. a drug is a biochemical substance formulated in such a way that when administered to a person it will exert a certain physiological effect. drugs include prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vaccines, and large-molecule biologic therapies. radiological devices ingested or applied locally do not count as drugs., the start date for the current instance of drug utilization. valid entries include a start date of a prescription, the date a prescription was filled, or the date on which a drug administration procedure was recorded.

the 'drug' domain captures records about the utilization of a drug when ingested or otherwise introduced into the body. a drug is a biochemical substance formulated in such a way that when administered to a person it will exert a certain physiological effect. drugs include prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vaccines, and large-molecule biologic therapies. radiological devices ingested or applied locally do not count as drugs., the start date and time for the current instance of drug utilization. valid entries include a start datetime of a prescription, the date and time a prescription was filled, or the date and time on which a drug administration procedure was recorded.

the 'drug' domain captures records about the utilization of a drug when ingested or otherwise introduced into the body. a drug is a biochemical substance formulated in such a way that when administered to a person it will exert a certain physiological effect. drugs include prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vaccines, and large-molecule biologic therapies. radiological devices ingested or applied locally do not count as drugs., the end date for the current instance of drug utilization. depending on different sources, it could be a known or an inferred date and denotes the last day at which the patient was still exposed to drug.

the 'drug' domain captures records about the utilization of a drug when ingested or otherwise introduced into the body. a drug is a biochemical substance formulated in such a way that when administered to a person it will exert a certain physiological effect. drugs include prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vaccines, and large-molecule biologic therapies. radiological devices ingested or applied locally do not count as drugs., the end date and time for the current instance of drug utilization. depending on different sources, it could be a known or an inferred date and time and denotes the last day at which the patient was still exposed to drug.

the 'drug' domain captures records about the utilization of a drug when ingested or otherwise introduced into the body. a drug is a biochemical substance formulated in such a way that when administered to a person it will exert a certain physiological effect. drugs include prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vaccines, and large-molecule biologic therapies. radiological devices ingested or applied locally do not count as drugs., the known end date of a drug_exposure as provided by the source.

the 'drug' domain captures records about the utilization of a drug when ingested or otherwise introduced into the body. a drug is a biochemical substance formulated in such a way that when administered to a person it will exert a certain physiological effect. drugs include prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vaccines, and large-molecule biologic therapies. radiological devices ingested or applied locally do not count as drugs., a foreign key to the predefined concept identifier in the standardized vocabularies reflecting the type of drug exposure recorded. it indicates how the drug exposure was represented in the source data and belongs to the 'drug type' vocabulary.

the 'drug' domain captures records about the utilization of a drug when ingested or otherwise introduced into the body. a drug is a biochemical substance formulated in such a way that when administered to a person it will exert a certain physiological effect. drugs include prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vaccines, and large-molecule biologic therapies. radiological devices ingested or applied locally do not count as drugs., the reason the drug was stopped. reasons include regimen completed, changed, removed, etc.

the note table captures unstructured information that was recorded by a provider about a patient in free text notes on a given date., a foreign key to the provider in the provider table who took the note.

the note table captures unstructured information that was recorded by a provider about a patient in free text notes on a given date., a foreign key to the visit in the visit_occurrence table when the note was taken.

the note table captures unstructured information that was recorded by a provider about a patient in free text notes on a given date., a foreign key to the visit in the visit_detail table when the note was taken.
the note table captures unstructured information that was recorded by a provider about a patient in free text notes on a given date., the source value associated with the origin of the note

the fact_relationship table contains records about the relationships between facts stored as records in any table of the cdm., the concept representing the domain of fact one, from which the corresponding table can be inferred.

the fact_relationship table contains records about the relationships between facts stored as records in any table of the cdm., the unique identifier in the table corresponding to the domain of fact one.

the fact_relationship table contains records about the relationships between facts stored as records in any table of the cdm., the concept representing the domain of fact two, from which the corresponding table can be inferred.

the fact_relationship table contains records about the relationships between facts stored as records in any table of the cdm., the unique identifier in the table corresponding to the domain of fact two.

the fact_relationship table contains records about the relationships between facts stored as records in any table of the cdm., a foreign key to a standard concept id of relationship in the standardized vocabularies.

the payer_plan_period table captures details of the period of time that a person is continuously enrolled under a specific health plan benefit structure from a given payer., a identifier for each unique combination of payer, plan, family code and time span.

the payer_plan_period table captures details of the period of time that a person is continuously enrolled under a specific health plan benefit structure from a given payer., a foreign key identifier to the person covered by the payer. the demographic details of that person are stored in the person table.

the payer_plan_period table captures details of the period of time that a person is continuously enrolled under a specific health plan benefit structure from a given payer., the start date of the payer plan period.

the payer_plan_period table captures details of the period of time that a person is continuously enrolled under a specific health plan benefit structure from a given payer., the end date of the payer plan period.

the payer_plan_period table captures details of the period of time that a person is continuously enrolled under a specific health plan benefit structure from a given payer., the source code for the payer as it appears in the source data.

the payer_plan_period table captures details of the period of time that a person is continuously enrolled under a specific health plan benefit structure from a given payer., the source code for the person's health benefit plan as it appears in the source data.

the payer_plan_period table captures details of the period of time that a person is continuously enrolled under a specific health plan benefit structure from a given payer., the source code for the person's family as it appears in the source data.
the cdm_source table contains detail about the source database and the process used to transform the data into the omop common data model., the full name of the source
the cdm_source table contains detail about the source database and the process used to transform the data into the omop common data model., an abbreviation of the name

the cdm_source table contains detail about the source database and the process used to transform the data into the omop common data model., the name of the organization responsible for the development of the cdm instance

the cdm_source table contains detail about the source database and the process used to transform the data into the omop common data model., a description of the source data origin and purpose for collection. the description may contain a summary of the period of time that is expected to be covered by this dataset.

the cdm_source table contains detail about the source database and the process used to transform the data into the omop common data model., url or other external reference to location of source documentation

the cdm_source table contains detail about the source database and the process used to transform the data into the omop common data model., url or other external reference to location of etl specification documentation and etl source code

the cdm_source table contains detail about the source database and the process used to transform the data into the omop common data model., the date for which the source data are most current, such as the last day of data capture
the cdm_source table contains detail about the source database and the process used to transform the data into the omop common data model., the date when the cdm was instantiated
the cdm_source table contains detail about the source database and the process used to transform the data into the omop common data model., the version of cdm used
the cdm_source table contains detail about the source database and the process used to transform the data into the omop common data model., the version of the vocabulary used

the care_site table contains a list of uniquely identified institutional (physical or organizational) units where healthcare delivery is practiced (offices, wards, hospitals, clinics, etc.)., a unique identifier for each care site.

the care_site table contains a list of uniquely identified institutional (physical or organizational) units where healthcare delivery is practiced (offices, wards, hospitals, clinics, etc.)., the verbatim description or name of the care site as in data source

the care_site table contains a list of uniquely identified institutional (physical or organizational) units where healthcare delivery is practiced (offices, wards, hospitals, clinics, etc.)., a foreign key that refers to a place of service concept id in the standardized vocabularies.

the care_site table contains a list of uniquely identified institutional (physical or organizational) units where healthcare delivery is practiced (offices, wards, hospitals, clinics, etc.)., a foreign key to the geographic location in the location table, where the detailed address information is stored.

the care_site table contains a list of uniquely identified institutional (physical or organizational) units where healthcare delivery is practiced (offices, wards, hospitals, clinics, etc.)., the identifier for the care site in the source data, stored here for reference.

the care_site table contains a list of uniquely identified institutional (physical or organizational) units where healthcare delivery is practiced (offices, wards, hospitals, clinics, etc.)., the source code for the place of service as it appears in the source data, stored here for reference.

the cohort table contains records of subjects that satisfy a given set of criteria for a duration of time., a foreign key to a record in the cohort_definition table containing relevant cohort definition information.

the cohort table contains records of subjects that satisfy a given set of criteria for a duration of time., a foreign key to the subject in the cohort. these could be referring to records in the person, provider, visit_occurrence table.
the cohort table contains records of subjects that satisfy a given set of criteria for a duration of time., the date when the cohort definition criteria for the person, provider or visit first match.

the cohort table contains records of subjects that satisfy a given set of criteria for a duration of time., the date when the cohort definition criteria for the person, provider or visit no longer match or the cohort membership was terminated.

the cohort_definition table contains records defining a cohort derived from the data through the associated description and syntax and upon instantiation (execution of the algorithm) placed into the cohort table., a unique identifier for each cohort.

the cohort_definition table contains records defining a cohort derived from the data through the associated description and syntax and upon instantiation (execution of the algorithm) placed into the cohort table., a short description of the cohort.

the cohort_definition table contains records defining a cohort derived from the data through the associated description and syntax and upon instantiation (execution of the algorithm) placed into the cohort table., a complete description of the cohort definition

the cohort_definition table contains records defining a cohort derived from the data through the associated description and syntax and upon instantiation (execution of the algorithm) placed into the cohort table., type defining what kind of cohort definition the record represents and how the syntax may be executed

the cohort_definition table contains records defining a cohort derived from the data through the associated description and syntax and upon instantiation (execution of the algorithm) placed into the cohort table., syntax or code to operationalize the cohort definition

the cohort_definition table contains records defining a cohort derived from the data through the associated description and syntax and upon instantiation (execution of the algorithm) placed into the cohort table., a foreign key to the concept to which defines the domain of subjects that are members of the cohort (e.g., person, provider, visit).

the cohort_definition table contains records defining a cohort derived from the data through the associated description and syntax and upon instantiation (execution of the algorithm) placed into the cohort table., a date to indicate when the cohort was initiated in the cohort table

the provider table contains a list of uniquely identified healthcare providers. these are individuals providing hands-on healthcare to patients, such as physicians, nurses, midwives, physical therapists etc., a foreign key to the main care site where the provider is practicing.

the provider table contains a list of uniquely identified healthcare providers. these are individuals providing hands-on healthcare to patients, such as physicians, nurses, midwives, physical therapists etc., the year of birth of the provider.

the provider table contains a list of uniquely identified healthcare providers. these are individuals providing hands-on healthcare to patients, such as physicians, nurses, midwives, physical therapists etc., the identifier used for the provider in the source data, stored here for reference.

the provider table contains a list of uniquely identified healthcare providers. these are individuals providing hands-on healthcare to patients, such as physicians, nurses, midwives, physical therapists etc., the source code for the provider specialty as it appears in the source data, stored here for reference.

the provider table contains a list of uniquely identified healthcare providers. these are individuals providing hands-on healthcare to patients, such as physicians, nurses, midwives, physical therapists etc., a foreign key to a concept that refers to the code used in the source.

the provider table contains a list of uniquely identified healthcare providers. these are individuals providing hands-on healthcare to patients, such as physicians, nurses, midwives, physical therapists etc., the gender code for the provider as it appears in the source data, stored here for reference.
